title: Why living near bad state schools can knock £14,000 off your house price
text:
Homeowners living in the catchment area of poor-quality state schools face a £14,000 penalty when selling their property.

A study by PwC, the auditors, shows that houses near the best schools in England have much higher sales prices than those next to average or poor quality schools. Those near the worst institutions face five-figure reductions on their house prices.

The research found that houses within the catchment area of the best 10pc of primary schools cost an average £27,000 more than similar homes in the wider postcode area. This is equivalent to a 7pc premium on the average home.
